Chapters.Title: 118  CHAPTER
Text:
of Basic Education 2014
118  CHAPTER 5 MAPWORK 
Mind the Gap CAPS Grade 12 Geography
Chapter
5
Method for calculating magnetic 
bearing
To get the true bearing and the magnetic declination we use the same 
methods applied in 5.3.3A (on page 111) and 5.3.3B (on page 112).
These methods are provided again below. Follow these steps:
Step 1: Measure the true bearing from A to B (as described in 5.1.3A)
Step 1a: Draw a straight line joining A and B.
Step 1b: Draw a north line through A (the point of measurement).
Step 1c: Place the 0 of your protractor at the top of the north line.
Step 1d: Moving in a clockwise direction from 0, read off where the line 
joining A and B touches the protractor.
Step 2: Calculate the magnetic declination (as described in 5.1.3B)
Step 2a: Work out the difference in years between the current year and 
year given on the map. Your answer must be in years. (Use the 
year that is printed straight after the words âtrue northâ. You can 
ignore the month that is shown.)
Step 2b: Multiply the number of years with the mean annual change (this 
is given on the map) to get the change since the declination 
was recorded.
Step 2c: If the mean annual change is eastwards, then you have to 
subtract the change from the magnetic declination given. If the 
mean annual change is westwards, then you must add it to the 
given magnetic declination.
Step 2d: Your answer is the magnetic declination for the current year. 
Magnetic declination is always west of true north.
Step 3: Now add the true bearing to the magnetic declination. Your 
answer must not have a direction (north, south, east or west) 
because it is an angle measured only in degrees and minutes.
Example 
MD = 18Â°,8 W = 17Â° 48â W
Change in years = 2012 â 1988 = 24 years
Change since 1989 = 24 Ã 4â = 96â W = 1Â° 36â W
MD = 17Â° 48â + 1Â° 36â 
 
= 18Â° 84â W = 19Â° 24â W
TB = between 299Â° and 303Â°
MB = TB + MD 
 
= 301Â° + 19Â° 24â
MB  = 320Â° 24â
Always write  
the formula  
MB = TB + MD  
in your calculations 
as this will earn you a 
mark.

To get the true bearing and the magnetic declination we use the same

These methods are provided again below. Follow these steps:
Step 1: Measure the true bearing from A to B (as described in 5.1.3A)
Step 1a: Draw a straight line joining A and B.
Step 1b: Draw a north line through A (the point of measurement).
Step 1c: Place the 0 of your protractor at the top of the north line.
Step 1d: Moving in a clockwise direction from 0, read off where the line 
joining A and B touches the protractor.
Step 2: Calculate the magnetic declination (as described in 5.1.3B)
Step 2a: Work out the difference in years between the current year and

ignore the month that is shown.)
Step 2b: Multiply the number of years with the mean annual change (this

Step 2c: If the mean annual change is eastwards, then you have to 
subtract the change from the magnetic declination given. If the

Step 2d: Your answer is the magnetic declination for the current year. 
Magnetic declination is always west of true north.
Step 3: Now add the true bearing to the magnetic declination. Your

because it is an angle measured only in degrees and minutes.
Example 
MD = 18Â°,8 W = 17Â° 48â W
Change in years = 2012 â 1988 = 24 years
Change since 1989 = 24 Ã 4â = 96â W = 1Â° 36â W
MD = 17Â° 48â + 1Â° 36â 
 
= 18Â° 84â W = 19Â° 24â W
TB = between 299Â° and 303Â°
MB = TB + MD 
 
= 301Â° + 19Â° 24â
MB  = 320Â° 24â
Always write  
the formula  
MB = TB + MD  
in your calculations 
as this will earn you a 
mark.
